newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Court charges Hebron gunman with attempted murder.
newsitem.headline: Court charges Hebron gunman with attempted murder.

text.p: An Israeli soldier who shot and wounded seven Palestinians in Hebron on New Year's Day has been charged with attempted murder, the army said on Tuesday.

It said a military court decided Noam Friedman, a 22-year-old conscript, was now fit to stand trial, after ruling last February that he must be confined to a psychiatric hospital and would not be charged.
"Because of the clear public interest in this case and because in contrast to the past Friedman is now fit to stand trial, an indictment was issued," the army said in a statement.
The indictment includes charges of attempted murder, insubordination and trying to persuade others to become accessories to murder, the statement said.
Friedman shot into a crowd of Palestinians in a Hebron marketplace on January 1 as Israel was negotiating the handover of most of the town to the Palestinian Authority.
He told the court later he was trying to prevent Israel and the PLO from reaching a deal.

A team of psychiatrists found Friedman was schizophrenic and he was confined to a mental facility. Last month he was moved to an open ward in the clinic and allowed to spend time at home, a decision that was bitterly condemned by Palestinians.
The statement said the army was asking the court to transfer Friedman, a religious Jew who lives in a West Bank settlement, back to the the closed ward.
An Israeli officer overpowered Friedman shortly after he opened fire from his M-16 automatic rifle.

Two weeks later Israel handed over 80 percent of Hebron to Palestinian self-rule under the terms of their peace deal. It retains control over 20 percent of the town where around 400 Jewish settlers live.
